content:
Suppose you have a groupoid XXX. Then there's groupoid A(X)A(X)A(X) where

  • an object is an object x∈Xx \in Xx∈X together with an automorphism g:x→xg: x \to xg:x→x
  • a morphism from g:x→xg: x \to xg:x→x to h:y→yh: y \to yh:y→y is an isomorphism f:x→yf : x \to yf:x→y making the obvious square commute: fg=hff g = h ffg=hf

What are some good ways to think about this construction, or interesting facts about it?

Some initial thoughts:

  1. We can get a groupoid this way if XXX is any category, but it only depends on the underlying groupoid of that category, called its [[core groupoid]], so we might as well just talk about groupoids.
  2. A(X)A(X)A(X) is the subcategory of the [[arrow category]] of XXX where the objects are only endo-arrows and the morphisms are only pairs of arrows that are equal.
  3. When XXX is the one-object groupoid corresponding to a group GGG, A(X)A(X)A(X) is the groupoid whose objects are group elements and whose morphisms f:g→hf: g \to hf:g→h are group elements such that fgf−1=hf g f^{-1} = hfgf−1=h. It's the [[weak quotient]] of GGG by itself, where it acts on itself by conjugation, so it's often called G//GG//GG//G. Since GGG acts on itself as group automorphisms, G//GG//GG//G is actually a [[2-group]], called the [[inner automorphism 2-group]] of GGG.
A(X)A(X)A(X) is also the [[powering]] of XXX by the circle groupoid, just as the arrow category is the powering by the interval category.
And if XXX is a category rather than a groupoid, it sits inside the analogous powering in Cat, which has the same objects but more morphisms where fff isn't required to be invertible.
Nice! In your reply, what 2-category (or if we have to go there, ∞\infty∞-category) are you thinking of as powered by what?

If it's Gpd powered by Gpd, do people say "powered" or "internal hom"?

Fumbling around here....

Maybe not very useful, but if f:x→xf:x \rightarrow xf:x→x is an endomorphism in a category C\mathcal{C}C, then we get an endofunctor 1f:C→C1_f:\mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}1f​:C→C defined by 1f(a):=x1_f(a):=x1f​(a):=x for every object aaa and 1f(u):=f1_f(u):=f1f​(u):=f for every morphism uuu. If we have two endomorphisms g:x→xg:x\rightarrow xg:x→x and h:y→yh:y \rightarrow yh:y→y, then a morphism f:x→yf:x \rightarrow yf:x→y such that the obvious square commute: fg=hffg=hffg=hf is exactly a natural transformation from 1g1_g1g​ to 1h1_h1h​.

Thus a morphism from g:x→xg:x \rightarrow xg:x→x to h:y→yh:y \rightarrow yh:y→y in your groupoid XXX is exactly a natural transformation from 1g1_g1g​ to 1h1_h1h​.

It explains why these morphisms feel like natural transformations: because they are natural transformations.
Oops, no sorry, it doesn't work ahah (the 1f1_f1f​ doesn't preserve identities).

The general notion of power is that if we have a category CCC enriched over VVV, there can be a power XKX^KXK for X∈CX\in CX∈C and K∈VK\in VK∈V. In your construction, C=GpdC=\rm GpdC=Gpd and you could take either V=CatV=\rm CatV=Cat or V=GpdV=\rm GpdV=Gpd. And you're right that when C=VC=VC=V, the power is the same as the internal-hom.
So maybe I should just have said that it's the functor groupoid out of the circle!
(This is the way in which the morphisms are natural transformations.)
I like to think of it as the power because then it generalizes nicely to other 2-categories, including Cat.
I'm glad you said "powering" instead of "internal-homming" both because it opened my mind and because it sounds nicer.
Applications perspective: if X smells like a concrete category, then the objects of A(X) resemble homomorphic encryption schemes. Really this is true for isomorphisms in any concrete category.

If we start with the fundamental groupoid XXX of some topological space, I wonder what the morphisms in A(X)A(X)A(X) are intuitively describing. In XXX, each automorphism is an endpoint-preserving homotopy equivalence class of loops, and f:x→yf:x \to yf:x→y is an endpoint-preserving homotopy equivalence class of paths from xxx to yyy. Then f∘g=h∘ff \circ g = h \circ ff∘g=h∘f says that doing loop ggg and then path fff gives the same result (up to endpoint-preserving homotopy) as doing path fff first and then the loop hhh.
Maybe there could be a nice way to visualize this condition, in terms of some specific paths?
publicatioin_quality.png

David Egolf said:

If we start with the fundamental groupoid XXX of some topological space, I wonder what the morphisms in A(X)A(X)A(X) are intuitively describing. In XXX, each automorphism is an endpoint-preserving homotopy equivalence class of loops, and f:x→yf:x \to yf:x→y is an endpoint-preserving homotopy equivalence class of paths from xxx to yyy. Then f∘g=h∘ff \circ g = h \circ ff∘g=h∘f says that doing loop ggg and then path fff gives the same result (up to endpoint-preserving homotopy) as doing path fff first and then the loop hhh.

Nice question. Maybe it's the fundamental groupoid of the [S1,Y][S^1, Y][S1,Y] where YYY is that topological space (alas, you didn't give it a name :cry:). [S1,Y][S^1, Y][S1,Y] is the topological space of continuous maps from the circle to YYY: remember, if we use a [[convenient category of topological spaces]], it will be cartesian closed, so the space of continuous maps from S1S^1S1 to YYY gets a topology.
[S1,Y][S^1,Y][S1,Y] is usually called the [[free loop space]] of YYY and denoted LYLYLY.

I'm not sure we have

Π1[S,T]≃[Π1S,Π1T] \Pi_1[S,T] \simeq [\Pi_1 S ,\Pi_1 T]Π1​[S,T]≃[Π1​S,Π1​T]

where A,BA,BA,B are nice topological spaces and Π1\Pi_1Π1​ is the fundamental groupoid; if it is then I think my guess is correct.
It certainly looks like that, but I suspect that it isn't exactly the same, because there was quotienting that happened in constructing the fundamental groupoid before taking the loops.

For instance, suppose YYY is a simply connected space with nontrivial π2\pi_2π2​, like the 2-sphere S2S^2S2. Then Π1Y\Pi_1 YΠ1​Y is trivial, and hence so is A(Π1Y)A(\Pi_1 Y)A(Π1​Y). But LYLYLY, while it may be connected, seems unlikely to have trivial π1\pi_1π1​. The lack of basepoints makes it tricky, but intuitively Π1(LY)\Pi_1(LY)Π1​(LY) should be saying something about π2(Y)\pi_2(Y)π2​(Y).

Yes, that sounds right. There may be a map one way between these two guys:

Π1[S,T]≃[Π1S,Π1T] \Pi_1[S,T] \simeq [\Pi_1 S ,\Pi_1 T]Π1​[S,T]≃[Π1​S,Π1​T]

maybe from left to right, since you're talking about how the right side has lost information.

Luckily for me my actual examples of interest aren't coming from topology - although every groupoid comes from topology if you want it to.
Another reason for the map to go left-to-right is that the thing on the right side has a mapping-in universal property.
